sentences.sentence: The attacks on the lockdowns from self-proclaimed economists, epidemiologists and opinion spruikers are wide of the mark.The lockdowns are one symptom of the problem; the virus is the cause.
It is like blaming the bomb shelter instead of the bomb.We are at war with the virus, not the remedies.

But if you read, listen to or watch mainstream media, you could be forgiven for thinking the problem was one vaccine or another, or the need to wear masks, socially distance or going into lockdown.They are not the problem.

The problem is an 18-month-old microbe called severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (Sars-Cov-2).The government of "stopping the boats" has failed miserably at its single most important job - protecting Australians.
It was the Morrison government that failed to stop passengers returning from their trips overseas bringing in the virus.

It was Peter Dutton's Department of Home Affairs that failed to stop the Ruby Princess and failed to maintain fit-for-purpose quarantine facilities.As Treasurer Josh Frydenberg said in Parliament, we have had the fastest recovery of any nation in the OECD.

Despite his own opposition to lockdowns, he has demonstrated that eradicating the virus is the only way to "open up for the economy".People won't learn to live with the virus: they will only learn to be sick and die with the virus.David LangsamFlemington, VicWe need leaders of greater substanceJennifer Hewett says "Scott Morrison seems more like a curiously passive onlooker than a proactive national leader" ("Cost of COVID-19 complacency is clear", June 30).

I agree, but there is worse.Instead of being a unifying national force above partisan politics and state parochialism during the pandemic, he and some of his ministers have sought political advantage by criticising Victoria in the dark days of its 2020 lockdown, instead of offering moral support and leadership to Victorians (and to other states) at a time of need regardless of politics.Unfortunately, the Governor-General cannot be the unifying force our nation needs - a strong argument for eventually moving to a republican system.
But that is an argument for another day.Sydney-Melbourne rivalry is nothing new: it has existed to varying degrees since the acrimonious separation of Victoria from NSW in 1851.

Scott Morrison lives in Sydney and his frequent anti-Victoria carping, coupled with smug advice that Victoria (with a Labor government) would do much better if it followed the "gold standard" of NSW (with a Liberal government), simply angered Victorians - especially when it came when we were at a low point in the COVID-19 lockdown.When you are down, you don't need a kick in the guts, but you do appreciate a supporting hand up - and you vote for leaders who offer it.Behind the fine words of the federal government, there is little substance - only a tired ideology wrapped in political expedience and tarnished by the peculiar Trump-like antics of the new Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce.Bob MuirheadPort Melbourne, VicPositive messagingis the missing pieceWhile it is imperative effective communication campaigns are implemented around COVID-19 vaccination programs, it is reasonable to ask why campaigns targeting obesity and cardiovascular disease are not part of the mix ("Let's be honest about the AZ vaccine", June 29).We are told the virus disproportionately affects the elderly and those with certain co-morbities such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes and the like.Yet many of us giggle that during the lockdowns we put on a few more kilos through eating and drinking more and sitting on the couch.

A positive message about doing what you can reasonably do to lower your risk of severe consequences of a COVID-19 infection, together with an effective campaign on vaccination, might empower people to take more control of their health and general wellbeing during these challenging times.Joanna WriedtEaglemont, VicKazakhstan eclipsingAustralia's gloryWith the results of the vaccination rates showing Kazakhstan at 10.3 per cent fully vaccinated and Australia at 4.8 per cent, maybe it's time for another Borat-like movie.Scott Morrison: Medical Learnings of Kazakhstan for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Australia.Dennis FitzgeraldBox Hill, VicVaccination recordtells another storyWow, what an article full of spin Pru Goward's is ("We have not failed on COVID-19", June 30).
Less than 5 per cent of Australians are fully vaccinated - towards the bottom of the list of vaccines delivered per capita in the world.
Goward is no epidemiologist.Natalia BradshawPotts Point, NSW

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: The attacks on the lockdowns from self-proclaimed economists, epidemiologists and opinion spruikers are wide of the mark.The lockdowns are one symptom of the problem; the virus is the cause. It is like blaming the bomb shelter instead of the bomb.We are at war with the virus, not the remedies. But if you read, listen to or watch mainstream media, you could be forgiven for thinking the problem was one vaccine or another, or the need to wear masks, socially distance or going into lockdown.They are not the problem. The problem is an 18-month-old microbe called severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (Sars-Cov-2).The government of "stopping the boats" has failed miserably at its single most important job - protecting Australians. It was the Morrison government that failed to stop passengers returning from their trips overseas bringing in the virus. It was Peter Dutton's Department of Home Affairs that failed to stop the Ruby Princess and failed to maintain fit-for-purpose quarantine facilities.As Treasurer Josh Frydenberg said in Parliament, we have had the fastest recovery of any nation in the OECD. Despite his own opposition to lockdowns, he has demonstrated that eradicating the virus is the only way to "open up for the economy".People won't learn to live with the virus: they will only learn to be sick and die with the virus.David LangsamFlemington, VicWe need leaders of greater substanceJennifer Hewett says "Scott Morrison seems more like a curiously passive onlooker than a proactive national leader" ("Cost of COVID-19 complacency is clear", June 30). I agree, but there is worse.Instead of being a unifying national force above partisan politics and state parochialism during the pandemic, he and some of his ministers have sought political advantage by criticising Victoria in the dark days of its 2020 lockdown, instead of offering moral support and leadership to Victorians (and to other states) at a time of need regardless of politics.Unfortunately, the Governor-General cannot be the unifying force our nation needs - a strong argument for eventually moving to a republican system. But that is an argument for another day.Sydney-Melbourne rivalry is nothing new: it has existed to varying degrees since the acrimonious separation of Victoria from NSW in 1851. Scott Morrison lives in Sydney and his frequent anti-Victoria carping, coupled with smug advice that Victoria (with a Labor government) would do much better if it followed the "gold standard" of NSW (with a Liberal government), simply angered Victorians - especially when it came when we were at a low point in the COVID-19 lockdown.When you are down, you don't need a kick in the guts, but you do appreciate a supporting hand up - and you vote for leaders who offer it.Behind the fine words of the federal government, there is little substance - only a tired ideology wrapped in political expedience and tarnished by the peculiar Trump-like antics of the new Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce.Bob MuirheadPort Melbourne, VicPositive messagingis the missing pieceWhile it is imperative effective communication campaigns are implemented around COVID-19 vaccination programs, it is reasonable to ask why campaigns targeting obesity and cardiovascular disease are not part of the mix ("Let's be honest about the AZ vaccine", June 29).We are told the virus disproportionately affects the elderly and those with certain co-morbities such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes and the like.Yet many of us giggle that during the lockdowns we put on a few more kilos through eating and drinking more and sitting on the couch. So, where is the Life. Be in it campaign? A positive message about doing what you can reasonably do to lower your risk of severe consequences of a COVID-19 infection, together with an effective campaign on vaccination, might empower people to take more control of their health and general wellbeing during these challenging times.Joanna WriedtEaglemont, VicKazakhstan eclipsingAustralia's gloryWith the results of the vaccination rates showing Kazakhstan at 10.3 per cent fully vaccinated and Australia at 4.8 per cent, maybe it's time for another Borat-like movie.Scott Morrison: Medical Learnings of Kazakhstan for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Australia.Dennis FitzgeraldBox Hill, VicVaccination recordtells another storyWow, what an article full of spin Pru Goward's is ("We have not failed on COVID-19", June 30). Less than 5 per cent of Australians are fully vaccinated - towards the bottom of the list of vaccines delivered per capita in the world. End of story. Goward is no epidemiologist.Natalia BradshawPotts Point, NSW
